discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In an IBGP network, the route reflector mechanism is used to reduce the number of BGP sessions required. Without route reflectors, every BGP router in the network would need to establish a session with every other BGP router (full mesh), which becomes inefficient in large networks.

 The route reflector itself is set up on the BGP router that will act as the central point for routing updates.
 On the client routers, you configure route-reflector-client enable to designate them as clients of the route reflector.

Summary:
To reduce the number of IBGP sessions, configure a router as a route reflector, and set route-reflector-client enable on its clients. Let me know if you need further clarification!

questions.question_text: Which configuration can be used to reduce the number of BGP sessions in an IBGP network?

choices.C: It supports rating requests from non-FortiGate devices.
choices.A: It can be configured as an update server, a rating server, or both.
choices.D: It provides VM license validation services.
choices.B: It caches available firmware updates for unmanaged devices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A. It can be configured as an update server, a rating server, or both

 True. When FortiManager is deployed as a local FortiGuard Distribution Server (FDS), it can act as:
 An update server for distributing antivirus signatures, IPS definitions, and other updates.
 A rating server for handling web filtering rating requests.
 Both roles can be configured depending on requirements.

B. It provides VM license validation services

 True. FortiManager can validate Fortinet VM licenses when acting as a local FDS, ensuring proper functioning of licensed Fortinet devices.

C. It supports rating requests from non-FortiGate devices

 False. FortiManager as a local FDS only supports rating requests from managed Fortinet devices (e.g., FortiGate, FortiClient, etc.).

D. It caches available firmware updates for unmanaged devices

 False. Firmware updates are cached only for devices that are managed by the FortiManager. Unmanaged devices cannot retrieve updates from it.

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are correct. B and C just don't make sense at all..

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are correct

choices.A: The access is blocked, based on the URL Filter configuration.
choices.D: The access is blocked if the local or the public FortiGuard server does not reply.
choices.C: The access is allowed, based on the FortiGuard Category Based Filter configuration.
choices.B: The access is blocked, based on the Content Filter configuration.

discussion.content: anyone recently wrote the exam share experience if this is still valid?

Selected Answer: C
This is the updated question:
A. Set strict-dirty-session-check enable command instructs the FortiGate to load all dirty session traffic to its SPU 
B. set check-protocol-header loose command enables hardware acceleration on this FortiGate device 
C. set av-fail open pass command instructs the FortiGate to load all traffic that uses the antivirus proxy to NP 
D. Set memory-use-threshold-extreme, command instructs the FortiGate to disable hardware acceleration, if the memory extreme threshold reaches 95%.

Selected Answer: C
the output does not explicitly reference any commands or parameters related to enabling or disabling Network Processors (NPs) or Content Processors (CPs). However, let's analyze the available settings for a conclusion:

 set av-failopen pass
 This indicates that antivirus scanning will allow traffic to pass even if the antivirus engine encounters an error. It does not directly affect the status of NPs or CPs.

 set check-protocol-header loose
 This loosens the protocol header checks for traffic. Again, this does not directly indicate the status of NPs or CPs.

 set memory-use-threshold-extreme 95
 This sets the memory utilization threshold at which extreme measures may be taken, but it does not indicate anything about NPs or CPs.

 set strict-dirty-session-check enable
 This ensures stricter checks on session consistency, but it does not influence the NP or CP settings.

Conclusion:

The configuration does not explicitly disable NPs or CPs. Therefore, the correct conclusion is:

C. NPs and CPs are enabled

Selected Answer: C
Strick - disabled all NPs and CPs
loose - Enables them

Therefore C is correct

C is the correct answer.
check-protocol-header strict diables all NPPs and CPs. Loose doesn't disable them.

P53 check-protocol-header strict disables all NPs and CPs.

"The option 'strict-dirty-session-check' will enable to check the session against the original policy when re-validating.
This can prevent dropping of redirected sessions when web-filtering and authentication are enabled together.
If this option is enabled, the FortiGate unit deletes a session if a routing or policy change causes the session to no longer match the policy that originally allowed the session. 
enable: Enable strict dirty-session check.
disable: Disable strict dirty-session check."
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-How-to-fix-fw-strict-dirty-session-check-drop/ta-p/224031
